task.summary: Default task

Edited the script so that the cleaned text is output to two separate files. 1 - The descriptions.csv 2 - The titles.csv Current issues: The single question is stored on multiple rows when it should only be on one row & column.

Working on getting breadcrumb.txt working correctly
Working on improving bot bypass, api proxy was banned

Ditched breadcrumbs Consolidated title and description to one file due to mismatch -- Thinking it may be a good idea to keep files separate
- Reason for issue with misalignment between files was one question description taking up multiple new lines due to 1. 2. ?
- Added google user agent to replace random user agent, better at avoiding detection. However it slows the retrieval speed significantly.
- Added option for automatic incrementation save of incrementer -- Ideally this would also write to file to save the last increment and restart if bot shuts down.
Backup before changing the iteration engine to a test site.

Fixed: - Questions decrementing on 403 - Saving to too many rows in csv - Simplified process for writing questions - fixed multiple heading printing
Added: - Encoding to Base64 to save line breaks and special characters - Saving to csv instead of txt file to make information easier to move to a database - Heading generator using csv Dict to place information in the correct rows and allow for easy appending of said rows - Saving of incrementation to a text file to preserve progress after system/program interrupt. - Methods to check if file exists for starting from incrementer.txt
Completed the addition of a category parser

Saving changes to scraper.py NO SELENIUM MERGING BETWEEN scraper.py and chromedriver-scraper.py
Committing changes of working version of scraper.py before experimenting with collecting webpage data using chromedriver-scraper.py with integrated cookie collection.
Issues in commit - scraper.py is blocked by chegg perimeterX service due to easily detectable web scraping techniques employed by BeautifulSoup.
Working on: - Working on a fix for scraper.py using selenium to trick perimeterX into thinking that the actions are not that of a bot.
## To start chromedriver-scraper.py is the experimental testbed for creating a bot that is not traditionally detectable by the employed PerimeterX system.
- It uses the selenium and the publicly available chromedriver to emulate the random actions of a user. - It should be as random as possible to avoid pattern recognition by "AI services" employed by PerimeterX. - It should save cookies for each session to avoid recaptcha. Recaptcha may have to be reset each day regardless. Recaptcha should be avoidable if collection is sufficiently randomized. - Should not go through each page in order? Possibly using a hashset to store question numbers. Implements random int and hashset to output next page to be scraped.

Effectively collects pages and uses the random list.
Needs to implement: 1. 'Show transcribed image text' to be recognizes and then instruct to parse the image text 2. Retrieving the iteration version from the text file and using that for later runs 3. Recognizing and a captcha on a page, then pausing the program and wait for user input 4. Once the captcha is solved, the program automatically(?) continues and the cookie is saved to a file and used on all sequential pages.

Experimenting with uMatrix_1.4.1b6.firefox.signed.xpi to block PerimeterX bot detection javascript when scraping sessions.
Still need to log in if scraping answers.
Added reading from incrementer, fixed output to csv from x to incrementer.

This is a now fully working due to umatrix blocking perimeterx js tracking. Code needs to be simplified down now that human behavior emulation is no longer necessary, neither is random question selection.
Latest changes before pushing changing webdriver to firefox.

Broke up everything into separate methods for increased modularity. Breaking up everything into modules had the unfortunate side effect of breaking the ability for the program to write to a csv file.
Currently working to restore functionality to the software while maintaining the modularity for future improvements.
Trying to get selenium to work by modifying the settings of umatrix before going through and copying pages from chegg to make for faster load times and possible compatibility with google chrome.

- Fixed bugs! 1. Now writes to the csv file 2. Modularity increased and main method added 3. Removed the dumb os selector and just manually wrote text input to umatrix instead of importing the file 4. figured out how global variables work in python, probably(?) fixed the existing global variables 5. Fix for NoneType concatenation for transcribed image text

Prototyping login for collection of question answer text and question answer images. Currently decided to not build out functionality for the automatic collection of question answers.
It takes noticeably longer to load the page when logged in. There seems to be no efficient means for downloading a specific image directly to a folder.
Logging in works automatically. Can now log in and extract text as well, not blocked by perimeterX.
Header names for all elements are different when logged in. It is a different site, so to collect questions when logged in will require an extra method for the different element/class names.
Improved on the menu for the application. Added more features for adjusting the values of question scraping.
Added multiple settings files for umatrix.
Version before editing to change write from csv to database.

Added adjustments to match database schema for django. Included T/F for whether a question has an answer or not.
To-Do: Fix transcribed question description capture

Implemented fix for collecting transcribed answer question definitions.
Note: Previous commit added a file for database writer. Database writer is an application specific for writing each question to a sqlite3 database in python; instead of being written to a csv.

Implemented direct database write with database_writer.py and added the template database for testing. --> confirmed success!
Ran the tool for a few minutes and figured out that at the current scraping rate, PerimeterX does in fact still block the tool, despite the CDN being blocked. Well... shit I guess
